Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Management of Left Ventricular Pseudoaneurysm

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of advanced multimodality imaging

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a tertiary care hospital, the study included patients with suspected or diagnosed LVP

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which received cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) and cardiac computed tomography (CCT) in addition to echocardiography, or the control group, which received standard echocardiography alone

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of advanced multimodality imaging in diagnosing and managing LVP

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the accuracy of LVP diagnosis, assessed over a 6-month period

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, with recruitment spanning from January 2020 to June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant improvement in diagnostic accuracy compared to the control group (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were minimal, occurring in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, primarily mild gastrointestinal side-effects

Funding.evidence: Funding: This study was supported by the National Institutes of Health
